home.title: Unified Service Management (USM)
home.lead: A universal method to bring simplicity and control to any service organization.
introParagraphs: USM provides one simple management system for all services – IT, facilities, HR, and more.
This site captures what USM is, why it matters, and how to start using it.

chapters.title: Chapter 7 – The Service Organization
chapters.shortSummary: How to structure a service organization: governance, domain separation, matrix organization, teams, and the service desk.
keyPoints: Mission, vision, core values, strategy, goals, and policy set direction.
Governance creates the environment; management runs the day-to-day.
Strategic, tactical, and operational levels are linked through planning & control.
Domain separation: specifying vs realizing to improve control and assurance.
Standardization and process/workflow-based working increase predictability.
RACI and clear profiles connect people to processes.
Service desk as SPOC; self-service and standardization shift work left.
Watch out for drama triangles and shadow services.

chapters.title: Chapter 8 – Technology Resources
chapters.shortSummary: What tools and templates a service organization needs, including the SDC tool and MIR.
keyPoints: Tools support coordination (workflows + MIR) and execution (task-specific tools).
Service Delivery Coordination (SDC) tool manages calls and workflows.
Managed Infrastructure Register (MIR) stores all managed components and relationships.

chapters.title: Chapter 9 – Deploying USM
chapters.shortSummary: How to introduce USM in practice using improvement sprints and change management.
keyPoints: USM can be deployed top-down, bottom-up, or both.
Use phases: intake, planning, set-up, improvement sprints, routine phase.
Internal project manager + optional USM coach + tool expert lead the work.
Organizational change management is crucial: attitude, behavior, culture.
USM works well with Agile, DevOps, Lean, and Design Thinking.
